remixed_from.author: FreakErn
remixed_from.title: LED strip holder for Anet A8

title: LED Strip Printer or Enclosure Mount (Anet A8 etc)

description.text:
After I added an LED strip under my extruder,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2277040

I wanted to "add some more light to the situation."

I liked the "LED strip holder for Anet A8"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004680

By
http://www.thingiverse.com/FreakErn

But I have never had any luck with the adhesive on LED strips... So I wanted to change the holder so It would secure the LEDs without relying on that glue.

So I changed the holder to be more like the one under my extruder, with the help of retaining walls and zip tie holes.

Then I thought, why not try using clear PLA and encase the LED strip and hopefully diffuse them a bit?

I also cannot use the part of spacer part of the original thing, because I am using a frame brace
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2243664
That replaces them.

So here we go. I uploaded a bunch of varieties, Some have holes for mounting under the Anet A8 LCD, and some have blank supports so you can drill your own holes.

Also there are ones with "lenses" which will only work with clear filaments.

I also added a lens version that can be surface mounted with screws. Great for an enclosure. You can use this thing to control the wires:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2284508

After trying to mount this, I realized it was to wide if you hare using the "Anet A8 corner braces"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2243664
So Ive made a shortened version of the lens version, which should save you from using the belt sander on the end.

The "Thingiverse" display has some problems resolving the things, but if you open them in your slicer they should be fine.

EDIT 05/03/17

Turns out if you print this in PLA and put it in an enclosure, and use cheap LED strips that get hot the ends tend to bend on the unsupported part, so I made a new version with supports.

I guess that's why they call it "rapid prototyping."

EDIT 5/5/17

The Angled surface mount came out so well that I made a drill guide for it to center the mounting holes.

My printer does a so-so job of making holes, but its never going to be as good as a drill bit, and its nice if you can change the hole diameter to match whichever screw you using.

You can skip all that and use double-sided tape.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printing at 100% is best for keeping the filament clear... I think.

author: GingerBrandon

description.text:
I recently started carrying my FPV drone flying gear in a backpack. The backpack works great, and it has a pocket that's just the right size for holding all the tools I usually carry.

Unfortunately, the loops inside that pocket are too small for my hex and nut drivers, and there aren't enough loops for all my tools. I've just been throwing everything in that pocket, but things quickly get stirred around, and I can never find the tool I'm looking for.

I designed this to hold my awesome set of Dynamite hex keys, my 8mm "prop" nut driver from Harbor Freight, and also my Harbor Freight flush cuts. Now I don't have to fish around in the pocket to find the right too. I can just pull them all out at the same time and use what I need!

The one I printed was a little too snug, so I had to sand it. I increased the diameters of all the holes by 0.2mm before uploading. I hope that does the trick!

print_settings.Notes:: I've printed this part on several different settings using a MakerBot Replicator 2. For speed purposes, I recommend printing with the lowest resolution. Infill thinking is similar, although it depends on how strong you need the hand to be. The part also prints great on a Dimension and Objet with standard settings.

description.text:
I created custom hands for my human-robot interaction work with the Rethink Robotics Baxter Research Robot. These hands are great for safe and comfortable hand-to-hand contact with Baxter. (And even if you don't have a Baxter robot, they can make an entertaining desk ornament or device for playful roughhousing.) The attached STL files contain a front and back piece for each of Baxter's hands. The pieces can be assembled using the protips below.

To attach the 3D-printed hands to the parallel rails with threaded holes on Baxter's wrist (as shown in the included picture of Baxter's wrist), you'll need two M4x0.7 screws per hand. The palm parts of the hand have holes on the back for standoffs (they'll press fit in if you print the hand on a makerbot, or you can glue them in if you print the hand on a higher quality 3D printer). Once the "palm" part of the hand is on the robot, you can put screws through the holes in the back-of-hand part and secure them in these standoffs to close up the hand.

I also typically fill the depressions in the hand with EcoFlex 10 silicone. To do this, I usually roll some modeling clay into a long cylinder and outline the outer edge of the hand with clay. Then I mold the silicone directly in the hand by pouring it into the indent until it is flush with the highest point of the clay. I do this on the front of the palm and the back of the back of the hand.

The roofs need to be printed at least a couple of millimeters above the build plate with support enabled to allow for the guides underneath and to ease in support removal. The rest of the pieces print with no support necessary. I would recommend a brim for the smaller pieces - the pole, the "goalpost," the steps and possibly the pool.

title: Ye Ol' Homestead
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: For years, I have wanted to build a scale model of my property. I even bought the artificial turf from a hobby store half a decade ago. I just never could find time to do it or the room in which to store a full scale, HO gauge, model. Enter the 3d printer. Using SketchUp to model the buildings and Google (gah... I hate the taste of that word!) Earth to model the terrain, I have recreated a relatively true-to-life recreation of my homestead. The roofs of both buildings are removable to show the interior floor plan. I have created this so that 1 scale mm = 1 foot in reality so that the terrain could be printed on the limited bed of my Tarantula. The buildings themselves, however, could very easily be scaled up for use in a model railroad layout, which I intend to do once I get my own layout started.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2

Notes:

The terrain needs to be printed with at least 10% infill using the "lines" pattern to support the top layers. The roofs need to be printed at least a couple of millimeters above the build plate with support enabled to allow for the guides underneath and to ease in support removal. The rest of the pieces print with no support necessary. I would recommend a brim for the smaller pieces - the pole, the "goalpost," the steps and possibly the pool.

I sprayed the terrain with a plastic adhesion primer. I then painted the grassy areas with a mixture of greens and browns using Plaid acrylic paints. The graveled areas received a similar treatment of greys. On top of that I spread a mixture of Elmer's glue and water to adhere the artificial turf - two colors - as well a real, finely powered gravel from the yard. Over that, I sprayed a light misting of a matte finish spray paint to keep everything in place. The individual pieces, printed in ABS, were all "glued" down using acetone.

The only element missing are the trees. I plan on trying to print a few using model I found here on Thingiverse, but if that doesn't work - they are small! - I will have to model those the old fashioned way.

author: alphap

description.text:
Brian's Parametric Micro Shelving

I created this thing when I needed to add a HDMI switch and a NETGEAR GS105NA 5-Port Gigabit Ethernet Network Switch to my multi-media set up. Space was in short supply where the devices were to be stored and I wanted to get them out of the way, but in a neat and orderly fashion.

After designing an object specific to my needs, I figured I'd turn it into a customizer for others to tweak to their own needs.

The shelving will automatically resize itself to the widest and deepest of the two devices. And then (if enabled) print a retaining wall of your desired length around each corner of the device to hold it in place.

Optional: Filing and Superglue as Needed

On my own print(s), I decided to file the legs slightly in order to get them to press-fit into their holes more easily.

Additionally, I decided to go ahead and superglue the legs on both sides. I intend to cram this into the back of my entertainment center and I didn't want any random jostling around of devices to knock it loose.

title: Ghostbusters Proton Pack Clippard valve assembled with text

description.text:
I assembled dancin fools clippard valve an made some changes. I liked the idea of recreating the text of the in actually part of the the real valve. My first try was too small so my printer software wouldn't pick up most of the detail. The end result is a little larger than I would like but I think it looks good. I also redesigned the knob with some extra detail.

There are 2 versions here one with the knob attached and one without. I had varying degrees of success printing with knob attached using support and no support. It was easier in the end to print as two pieces and then epoxy together.

I taped off the lower section and then sprayed the upper "chrome" the end result looks pretty good.

author: hprotzek

description.text:
An OpenSCAD module to render a 2D polygon outline including rounded vertices/corners.

It takes a list of vertices as [X,Y] points (vec2), a boolean value for whether to fill the polygon, and a float of the thickness of the outline. The points lie in the centre of the circles which form the outline's vertices.
It supports both filled and unfilled polygons.

Example Usage
use <OutlinePolygon.scad>
Points = [ [0,0], [0,1], ...];
linear_extrude(5) {
    OutlinePolygon(lineThickness=4, fill=false, points=Points, $fn=24);
}

print_settings.Notes:: This is designed to allow you to test a range of extrusion percentages or a set of temperatures in one print.  You can make the cube whatever size, thickness or height you want.  You can print marks every few millimeters or not.

description.text:
This is an open topped test cube - you can make the cube the size you want (stl is 15x15x40 with walls 0.48mm thick) and it can have marks every few millimeters (or not) to allow you to see where changes are made. The openSCAD source is included (it is very simple) as is a sample test cube in gcode (which will print centered around 0,0 for a delta).

I hope that people find this useful.

Printer:

HE3D K280

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

your choice, what do you need to model

Infill:

none

Notes:

This is designed to allow you to test a range of extrusion percentages or a set of temperatures in one print. You can make the cube whatever size, thickness or height you want. You can print marks every few millimeters or not.

openSCAD is your friend

So, when I look at something like this, I think of how to turn it into shapes. OpenSCAD makes that simple. A cube is an extruded square within a square. A bottom is a cube. The rings are extruded squares that are allowed to grow (so that the are not overhanging shelves.

The cool thing is that you can download openSCAD (free) and you can change any of the parameters, and you can made a 5mm test cube, or a test cube with 0.66mm walls, or a 100mm tall test cube with marks every 10mm or whatever you want or need for your project.

I have included one set of gcode. The gcode is centered on 0,0 and it changes temperature every 3mm by 3 degrees - 210C at the first mark, down 3C every mark.

remixed_from.title: i3 Adjustable Y Belt Holder for GT2 & T2.5

description.text:
WIP! Just finished the designs, about to start building the parts and drill guides this week and will be able to work out kinks from there.

Still to do:

  • Endstop mounts
  • Drill guide for the front pillow blocks
  • adjust height/spacing for fan blower duct

I had a lot of fun converting my Replicator to a RAMPS 1.4 open source kit, but I was plagued by persistent issues, problems with the extruders jamming, play in the Y-axis causing some difference in the print walls depending on which direction the perimeter was printed. Eventually one of the 5mm rods on the Y-axis bent, causing variances in tension that would in turn cause prints to fail. I guess that's what happens when you pull an old printer out of E-Waste ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I've always been facinated by the concept of a CoreXY setup and figured this was a perfectly good opportunity to simultaneously fix some of the remaining issues with my printer, as well as explore a new style of kinematics.

Hardware Required:
8x GT20 5mm Pully Idler (toothed or smooth, doesnt matter)
2x MR105ZZ bearing (5x10x4mm)
4x M5 30mm countersunk bolt
2x M3 30mm bolts
4x M3 25mm bolts
8x M3 4x5mm embedded nuts
Various shorter M3 nuts and bolts

For those who would like to customize or make changes for themselves, here's the Tinkercad

title: Ultimate Ball Bearing Spool Holder 3000
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
If you have issues with your extruder tugging on a stubborn spool, this is the holder for you! This design utilizes Ball Bearings which allow the spool to spin and feed filament smoothly. So Super Satisfyingly Smoooooooth!

I designed this Spool Holder from the ground up as a replacement to the stock spool holder on my Aurarum Wombot Exilis XL but should work well on similar 30mm extruded frames.

The insert assembly comes in 2 parts, an inner half and outer half and fits 30mm spool holes. The grooves allow the (2 Optional) Spool Hole Diameter Adapters to slide on and better fit common 50mm and 55mm spool holes. The ends of both halves fit nicely into ball bearings which are hot glued to the spool arms.

Printed Parts: 1x Outer Half, 1x Inner Half, 2x Spool Arms, 2x Spool Adapters (Optional)
Requires: (2) 8mm Inner Diameter , 22mm Outer Diameter Ball Bearings

Depending on the tolerances of your printer, you may need to drill a hole on the outer half to prevent pressure or suction when removing two halves.

If you need a similar spool holder for a different style printer, send me a msg and I'll consider tweaking the design.

Printer:

Aurarum Wombot Exilis XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20

Notes:

Depending on the tolerances of your printer, you may need to drill a hole on the outer half to prevent pressure or suction when removing two halves.
I printed the Outer half upside down with a wide brim. This allows for better bed adhesion and for the use of less support material vs printing upright.
If you tend to have poor layer adhesion, you should reinforce the ball bearing insert tips with a layer or two of super glue or glue a sturdy insert into the tip to prevent heavy spools from breaking the tip.

Post Printing

Light sanding may be recommended to the inner half so that it can easily slide in and out of the outer half for faster and easier filament changing.

Fusion360

Designed in Fusion360.

title: Glass Plate Holder Bed Clip for Geeetech I3X / PCB Heatbed MK2a

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/36PdEdivk5g

This is my first created thing...

I could not find a glass clip that fits exactly to my Geeetech I3X printer so i remixed one to fit.
I used thinkercad for this.

It is so designed, that you can use the original countersunk screws from the printer.

Because my bed was not exactly 200x200x4 i had to went with the 6,5 mm whide clips.

The clip has a thickness of 4 mm.

200x200x4 = 7,0 mm clip (you need 4 pieces)
201x201x4 = 6,5 mm clip (you need 4 pieces)
202x202x4 = 6,0 mm clip (you need 4 pieces)

I needed no brim/raft or something, i printed it flat on bed with 0,2 mm layer hight and 100% infill.

Update 02.05.2017:

Made versions for asymmetric glassplates.
Included the mirrored clip in stl file so you only need 2.

200x201x4 = 6,5+7,0
201x202x4 = 6,0+6,5

description.text:
This is a cable clip intended for cables small in diameter. The biggest that will fit in this cable clip is about 4.5mm in diameter.

Can be mounted with a screw (~4mm diameter) or with double sided adhesive. I recommend using a screw, as there's not much surface area for the adhesive to grip, and it may come off after some time.

Great for Lightning/USB charging cables, .35mm TRS jack cables, or slim laptop power cables (DC end).

title: Tippmann M4 Buffer Tube Spacers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Its another tube! WOW that's so hard to make!

Just another part to save someone a few minutes

Included is the 3/4 , 1 and 1 3/4 Inch Premade stl files
and a flat sketchup file so anyone can make a custom length.

Works and installs the same as the original Tippmann product. Just make sure you remove the upper from the lower before removing the buffer-tube. This will prevent damage and cracking of the upper receiver.

The bigger the spacer the bigger recoil boost, and fps boost. and also a loss in efficiency very apparent on c02 magazines. Can also increase consistency

I have not had a chance to test these long term. But should hopefully last.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dXGZY71XYSb

A pillow, for keeping your head comfortable while you watch netflix or for contemplating the nature of cellular automata. The vectors were generated using a small python script which simulates Conway's game of life. You can find some interesting patterns to generate on the Conway's game of life wiki: http://www.conwaylife.com/wiki/Conway%27s_Game_of_Life

Iron transfer paper to an accent color fabric. Cut patterns out of fabric using a laser cutter or a cutting machine such as the Silhouette Cameo. Iron pieces to another piece of fabric, sew around the edges using a wide stitch on a sewing machine. Sew to another piece of fabric around all edges, and stuff. Now you have a pillow,

Bracket for camera mount.
Rest parts here

I recommend the Fat Ribs version as other versions cracked on PETG when screwing. (you will also have to remove half of old mounting and thread the cameras plastic by using an M4 x 45 Bolt. In the photo you can see the Fat Version

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1228521

I've put a match box so that you could understand the scale.
There are two DWG files. Frog_original is what I've actually cut and had to adjust manually (please see the photo with 3 parts). Original design has some flaws in sense of symmetry as well, so I attach it following principle "as is". Frog_edited is my attempt to reflect these manual changes in the design. The altered parts have green colour in it. Please note, I haven't cut frog_edited so far.

OpenSCAD bend procedures
compatibility 2017.x

When extruding DXF files in OpenSCAD, your options are rather limited - the extruded DXF always forms a plane.

This procedure allows to bend the extruded file (or basically any model) on the surface of a cylinder or into a parabola.

Instruction (how to work):

  1. Place the target in the paralellepiped from [0,0,0] to ["dimension"].
  2. Bend around axis parallel X and with Z-coordinate equal "radius", i.e. F(x,"0","radius")
  3. The object will be divided into "nstep" pieces along the Y axis. First piece is not changes. Each next piece will be rotated relative to the axis F(x,"0","radius") arount piece center Y-coord.

Upd: Fix 360 degree included.
See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2299059 for more examples

description.text: For the most part, adapters are versatile, allowing very dissimilar fixed ports to play well together. Unfortunately, sometimes adapters are inconvenient. They can be heavy, clumsy, or insecure. In this case, all 3 maladies elicited a custom dust shroud for the Kreg Pocket Hole Master System ensuing in a lightweight and secure direct connection to my Festool CT dust extractor 27 mm hose. For a short video of why this came to be, check out the full blog post at http://tool-torials.com/027-festool-kreg-dust-shroud/
Both left (pictured) and right port options available. Print with open side facing up to reduce build time and support material.

comments.text: I printed this with Octave blue ABS and the color is just about a dead match for Kreg blue. It snaps into my pocket hole jig perfectly. The hose side is a less perfect fit, I printed the larger size and the Festool 27mm hose is too big to fit nicely inside and the 35mm hose needs too much convincing to fit over the outside. I printed this twice, the first time with the hose to the bed as recommended and it came out fine, but the finish left after removing the support wasn't attractive. So I printed it again with the hose side up and it looks great, but took much longer to print. The hose fit issue happened with both.

comments.text: Just wanted to say thanks for sharing this!  My wife is going to love all of the photography studio stuff I can see myself making her using these components.  For anyone in the same boat as henlego, understand that PVC will vary from manufacturer to manufacturer, and you will have to be able to adjust the .stl for ANYTHING based on using PVC on thingiverse.  There is no way a designer can account for all of the different variances between manufacturers, especially on a global level.
comments.author: SimplyTim

comments.text:
Are those the right pvc sizes? It seems like the way pvc pipes are sized are by the inside diameter.
I got some schedule 40 1/2" pvc pipe and the inside diameter is 0.587 inches, the outside is 0.838 inches.
the part: 03-joint-small.stl has an inside diameter of 0.573 inches, which is too small for schedule 40 1/2" pvc pipe.
there is a similar story for the other parts as well.

description.text: A greeting card which looks like a small pinwheel-pattern quilt, so you can up your sewing cred with the quilters in your life.

Use a laser cutter or a cutter like a silhouette cameo. Cut pinwheel_1.dxf out of white cardstock, or a lighter colour. This will be the accent in the pinwheel. Cut pinwheel_2.dxf out of darker cardstock. This piece will be the border.   
Colour the four pinwheels on the accent piece using markers. Or don't, if you hate freedom.  
Glue the accent piece to the main piece of your card. Glue the border piece to this piece. Then it is done.

Bore the 3.2mm holes for the screws and insert three M3 thread inlets (one in each clip, and one in the base). You need 2x M3x16 screws to fix the clips, another M3x10 and M3 hex nut to fix the hotend on the clips (it increases the pressure to hold it stiff). Just slip the heatsink into the clips, mount the clips on the base and use the fixation to make a proper mount. Keep tolerances in mind and don't overtighten everything :)

For the Blower Fan Mount you need 1x M3x24 screw and a M3x22 screw and a M3 Hex Nut. Glue the little fan duct on the blowing end (check orientation before glueing!) and screw the mounting plate and blower fan on the single thread inlet.

description.text: The photos show the tank and tank top fitted to my India Mills 1.3cc engine. Both parts were missing from my engine. The tank and tank top are matched together for size. I doubt whether the tank on its own would fit an original metal tank top from a Mills 1.3cc engine. The tank has a wall thickness of 1mm near the top thickening to 1.5mm at the bottom. It's printed in translucent PLA at a layer height of 0.2mm at 100% fill. The tank top is printed in silver grey PLA at the same settings. The 4 lugs on the tank top are printed vertical as shown and warmed with a heat gun to bend slightly inwards to grip the tank. PLA seems to be model diesel fuel proof however the print is slightly porous and when filled drips slightly. To counteract this I sealed the inside. This is done with Plastic Weld, a watery solvent for PLA. This is poured inside and worked around with a clean brush for a few seconds to dissolve the inner surface then poured out and left to set.

description.text: Greetings! Happy to share my printed enclosure for a wearable digital vcard. Being on active jobsearch i tried out this pretty eyecatcher visiting a fair last week. It's a nextion 2.8" touch-display inside a remixed version of the manufacturers bezel. Touching the name and the icons leads to a vcard-QR-code and some pretty pictures. Driven by 2 AAA-cells it stayed visible/usable for around 12 hours (quick and dirty approach, small rechargeable battery will come in the future). Very easy to make, just print and solder on the battery cable. Holes for the cord were drilled afterwards to gain some stability. Printed with supports so the top-side gets a nice finish. Hope you like it ;-P

title: Micromake C1 upper bearing assembly modification

description.text:
This is a modification of the upper bearing assembly of the Micromake C1.
The stock assembly has poor load bearing characteristics, that cause the whole assembly to flex and misalign the bearings and the belt. This misalignment causes the belt to wear prematurely (visible after just 16 hours of operation).

This modification replaces the stock assembly and has much better load bearing characteristics, keeping the bearings and the belt perfectly aligned, reduces vibrations as well. Belt tensioning functionality is maintained.

Join our dedicated Micromake C1 community on Google+.

https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/107601566777965101182

Share your questions, wisdom, experience and modifications with other owners.

description.text:
YOU MUST HAVE AUTO BED LEVELLING FOR THIS TO WORK

A simple gantry to hold a cheap cork tile to the bottom of the hotbed without glue or tape. Can be printed in PLA as the cork protects it from the heat of the bed.
The dovetail joints should just click together and hold.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The joints should just click together. The bed screws will be quite a tight fit as they provide the lift at the centre to hold the cork tile in place.

Instructions

Get a cheap cork tile from a DIY shop, cut the corners off to allow for the bed screws, cut a hole in the centre to allow airflow around the thermistor, and cut a section of cork out where the wires join the board.

Build the bed supports and lay on the Y carriage, place the cork and bed on top, and put the screws through the whole thing. Don't over tighten as this can warp the bed.

print_settings.Notes:: Best printed laterally placed on the bed.

title: Anet A8 vibration damping feet - new version

description.text:
A new version of the anti-vibration feet. Smaller footprint and lower height with a double spring.

This won't improve print quality but will make your printer much quieter.

This version has a cut-out on the bottom for a 10mm x 10mm adhesive rubber pad.

Also included a low profile version and a half low profile version for the front frame with a frame brace. Take the frame brace off and file a small notch for the foot to clip into.

Print out 8 feet, 2 for the back frame, 2 for the front frame and 2 for each side behind the z-motors.

Several people have asked where to put the feet so I've added an image indicating where I've put them. Hopefully it'll help. Thanks to @SmallArtFly for the image from his thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2288314

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

any
Add a small 10x10mm self-adhesive rubber pad to the bottom to prevent the printer sliding around.

title: Lasercut Stackable Storage (Rock Box)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Stackable storage I designed for carrying lapidary slabs back and forth to my club/workshop. These boxes are divided into two plans one cuts two 4x6x6 inch boxes and associated dividers the other cuts one 4x6x12 inch box. These boxes are a thing unto themselves, that I use for storing rock materials on my basement storage shelves, and are not compatible with my Ikea stackables. They are designed for easy carrying and to hold modest amounts of weight. I transport them on the passenger seat of my car, they do not survive well rolling around in the trunk of the car full of rocks. The provided templates (both pages) are designed with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. You can customize them at your own leisure with labels and text.

Formatted for cutting on two 3mm MDF cut from (Arch C) 24" x 18" sized sheets, which each fit across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

author: YellowSignStudio

description.text: A pillow, for sticking under your behind, or for starring at and thinking about the nature of fractals whilst drunk or sleep deprived. Made using Processing, and by modifying this example code: http://joyofprocessing.com/blog/2011/11/hilbert-curve/ Then I saved the screen, and used inkscape's trace bitmap function to generate the dxf. I suppose I could have exported to a vector format, but sometimes I'm rushed (see above).

Iron transfer paper to accent fabric. Cut accent fabric using a laser cutter or a cutter such as a Silhouette Cameo. Spend about an hour pulling off the back of the transfer paper and then untangling the piece. Iron to a large square piece of fabric. Sew around the edges using a wide stitch on a sewing machine. Cry at the amount of time this project has ended up taking. Sew this piece to another all around the edge and stuff. Now you have a pillow.

description.text:
For those how don't want to change every time the filament spool ...
I propose you to make a cheap and very useful Filament Spool Holder.

You'll only need to spend 5€ for the aluminium profiles and 3€ in filament (I used PLA)

Materials:

Printable:
Corner_x8.
Holder_Initial_Final_x2.
Holder_Middle_x4.

Not printable:
Aluminium profile 10x10x500 mm x 7
Aluminium profile 10x10x125 mm x 4

UPDATE:
Added a filament guide for each color.
(additionally you can use a filter for the filament)

Printer:

BQ Hephestos 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used supports for the corners and for the Holder_Middle_x4

Total PLA used: 194gr.
Corner 3gr x 8 = 24gr
Holder_Initial_Final 23gr x 2 = 46gr.
Holder_Middle 31gr x 4 = 124gr.
Filament Guide: 4gr x 5 = 20gr.

Total time:
Corner x 8 = 3h
Holder_Initial_Final x 2 = 4h.
Holder_Middle x 4 = 10h.
Filament Guide x 5 = 2h.
Insert all the corners into the aluminium profile (you will need a hammer) except the two upper profiles (to assemble the holders) Introduce one by one all the holders.

author: santa25

description.text:
Ever offended, that its so hard with your vacuum cleaner to clean of your rooms ?
Here comes the solution. With this tool you can raise the dust, while you clean it.
Its basically a rotating brush which is driven by the Vacuum.

You will need:

  • Printed: Adapter, Holder, Impeller, Orifice
  • 2 Bearing 624ZZ
  • M4x 50 Screw with 30mm without thread
  • Lots of M4 Washers with lots of weight
  • 5 M3x6 skrews
  • 2 M3 nut
  • Cotton Sticks
  • M5 Nut
  • Vacuum Cleaner with 30mm Hose Diameter

Instructions

  • Print and clean the 4 Parts
  • Cut 3 Cotton Sticks to 25 mm length
  • Insert the 2 Bearings into the Holder
  • Insert the m3 nuts into the impeller and into the Adapter
  • Insert the M4 Skrew into the Adapter and fix it with a M3 Skrew
  • Insert the M5 Nut into the Adapter. It acts as a separator
  • Insert the Holder onto the M4 Skrew
  • Insert and Glue the Washers onto the M4 Skrew. They act as a Balance Wheel
  • Insert the Impeller onto the end of the M4 Skrew and fix with a M3 Skrew
  • Iinsert the Cotton Sticks onto the Adapter. Once they are gone, just insert new ones.
  • Mount the Orifice onto the cotton sticks using the remaining 3 skrews.

Get a demonstration of dustbuster in action at

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ODWUU7yUk8A

Happy Cleaning!

description.text: A crossword puzzle card - you have to solve the crossword on the outside to read the message inside.

If you put your crossword in CSV format, such as the example in.csv, the perl script "make_crossword_svg.pl" to generate the vector. Then, you can cut the vector out on cardstock using a laser cutter or a cutter like a Silhouette Cameo. The inside of the card contains the message - I did this by hand, a future addition would be to add to the perl script code for generating this vector. For example, the message on this card is:
1 Across: Good
30 Across: bye
8 Down: Kelsey
12 Across: Have
43 Down: fun
13 Across: in
38 Across: Zurich print off the puzzle clues and include them with the card.

print_settings.Notes:: I used supports for the pole as trying to print it without made a horrible mess.

description.text:
Got a problem with the signal from my router upstairs so needed a way to move the wifi dongle away from the laptop while sitting at the kitchen table. Had this idea and used Tinkercad for this little stand that holds the USB 2.0 extension cable.

Dimensions of the top for the USB to slide into are 8mm X 14mm which is just enough room for the metal part of the extension cable.

Update:
A friend popped in last night and saw my wifi dongle stand and asked if he could have one but mounted on the laptop lid. Have now uploaded this laptop lid holder. Made it 14mm wide gap to fit on top of the screen with a 10mm overhang on the screen side.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The infill I used was 100% for the 8mm pole and the 50mm base and only 20% for the top.
One thing I noted was because the base is small the stiff USB cable tended to roll the stand over. To stop this I printed out a second base and gently knocked this onto the bottom of the stand.

I used supports for the pole as trying to print it without made a horrible mess.

description.text:
Disguised as a wall mounted spool holder 3D Printing Guardian watches over the whole 3D printing process. He immediately made our lives easier as now we can replace a spool in seconds. It is especially handy when changing filament for multicolor 3D printing. The idea was to design something functional but with an interesting theme to it. That’s how our 3D Printing Guardian was born.

NB! Mace screw system is fragile - please do NOT overtighten it when screwing the mace parts together. If the screw system gets broken, just print out the reinforcement rings. See the picture.

description.text:
Trois pignons entrainés, impossible normalement.
Ici on peut monter le pignons dans les deux sens , ça fonctionne, à cause des pignons paradoxaux.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sCZaAkjUcpg&feature=youtu.be
Il faut imprimer trois pignons identiques, 3 rondelles, un support 3 axes, une bride clip haute.
Fonctionnement très fluide et surprenant!
Three drive sprockets, normally impossible.
Here the gables can be mounted in both directions, it works, because of the paradoxical gables.
It is necessary to print three identical sprockets, three washers, a support 3 axes, a clip high clip.
Very fluid and surprising operation!

NOP21

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

comments.text: IMPORTANT - one of the three gears must be inverted for these to fit together.  No re-scaling or anything needed, just turn one of the three identical gears upside down (before or after printing) to get it all to slip into place perfectly.  Very neat design. Really enjoyed this one.

title: Raspberry Pi Case - Wall Or Monitor Mounted With HDMI Option

description.text:
Fixing Holes are 4off M4 100mm x 55mm

Wall mountable case for a Raspberry Pi, also can be mounted to a 100mm Vesa mount. Ideal for use with display panels (CCTV) or other network devices.

Please Note: Don't forget to adjust the regulator board to 5V BEFORE connecting the Raspberry Pi, these boards are shipped with the adjustment turned up high and will damage your Pi!

The reason I used a regulator board to power the Pi is that 12V wall adaptors are more common place than good 5V 2A ones, also I don't like the flimsy micro USB connectors. The current draw at @12V for this finished unit was around 130mA when using a B+, maybe a little more for a Pi 3.

Parts
3off M3 Brass Inserts
3off M3 6mm Bolts
6off No Screw 6.5mm
1off Regulator Board Ebay (Search for "Output 1.23V-30V DC-DC Buck Converter Step Down Module LM2596 Power Supply")
1off DC Jack
1off 1N4001 Diode
1off 5mm LED plus Resistor (could be single colour or RBG)
1off Raspberry Pi

title: Minecraft Ore Lamp Cube Block - Red Stone / Diamond / Gold / ect.

description.text:
A cube that you print and assemble to create a minecraft ore lamp.  Using different LEDs, you can use red for red stone, yellow for gold ore, and blue for diamond ore.  If you know someone who likes minecraft, they will love this!  My kids do!  
Works with any 1W or 3W "Star" type LED...  Use different colors for different ores!  I have red too, but didn't get a picture of it!  Turn several of them on in a dark room and you get an awesome collage of 8 bit colors all over the walls and ceiling!  
Please don't use anything larger than 3W as they get very hot and may cause a hazard.  I think 1W works great and 3W is a bit over kill.

Print the top, side one twice and side 2 twice.  Glue both side 1 and side 2 to the top creating a sort of pyramid.  Invert the second side 1 and 2 so the patterns don't match up and glue them opposite the original side 1 and 2 so you now have a cube without a bottom.  
You need a 1W or 3W "Star" type LED in your preferred color.  There is a recess in the bottom piece to mount the LED.  Heat stake the LED into place (melt the plastic post that the LED slides in between with a soldering pen and squish down the plastic, locking the LED into place)  
This was designed to use a battery holder with a switch.  The part number for the battery holder I used is SBH-321AS.  This is for 2 AA batteries which output roughly 3.2V, so purchase an LED accordingly or use a resistor to obtain proper voltage.  
Solder the battery holder to the LED and then glue the bottom to the cube you glue together out of the other sides.  Put batteries in it and snap the battery holder into the base.   Flip it on and see the kids ooh and ahhh over it!  
I got this idea from MaximFilms and his Minecraft Diamond ore lamp thing # 37173...  I was working with his trying to get things to work with the LED and the battery holder I had.  I wound up starting from scratch and completely re-drew the entire model.  But Kudos goes to him for the inspiration!

Orientation of part 7,8,9 is not correct in stl.The montage pin has to be on top.
For part 11 I added supports manual on the outside of the fins only (rest was done by bridging).

This is only a decorative thing.

I created a curved LED bar for my helping hands to aid in the SMD component placement and PCB inspection.

It runs 4 strips of 9 white leds in parallel providing blinding light.

I used knurled inserts to prevent the stripping of PETG and failure from repeated use. If this were to be remixed I would have inserted the knurled insert from the opposite side I have them on the LED mount. Currently they are able to be pulled out if not set properly.

The throat for the led mount is 9mm and can be detached so that it can be placed around a component with minimal deconstruction of the helping hands.

It uses M3 hardware.

comments.text: Those are standard 60mm, 12v, fans.  Ideally 1cm thick but if you get thicker ones the one over the RAMPS can be mounted on the outside of the case.  You can power them from the internal powersupply...either hardwired to in power so they are on whenever the printer is on or you can connect them to the power supply that is controlled using M106 P1 S255.

Stopper (a cup) for protectional tubes (in Czechia this tube is known as Kopoflex tube). This stopper is for 40mm diameter, and is inserted externally. I made this design because stoppers are not available so much.

This stopper is for covering against dust, stones etc.
If you need longer time cover, you can glue it with neutral silicone.

Kopoflex tube and original cup is on picture.

Here our Jellyfish, its hollow and prints great. When you put a Air Plant inside it to give it a complete air jelly look. Looks cool hanging in our living room window. Our cats love to sit and stare at them for hours on end. These fun hanging jellies brighten up any room! Hang them inside or outside.   
We use many kinds of Air Plants. This particular plant is called "Tillandsia". They have no stems, they have no roots, and their leaves don't look anything at all like leaves and they require no soil at all, either, and don't live in the ground. They still need some water, we just put some distilled water in a sprayer and give it a good mist, a few times a week and should be good to go, in the right sunlight and conditions.'  
You can find other species of air plant to fit your Air Jellies. Shop at some online nursery.

Designed using Autodesk 123d Design Printer: Solidoodle 3rd Gen
1.75mm filament
No Supports needed
1 - 3mm prints great

comments.text: This is really cool! I'd love to have one hang around in my apartment.
comments.author: janinius

comments.text: This is amazing looking but I have to ask - how on earth are you keeping the Air Plants in the "jellies"? They look amazing, enough that I want to print a set and pick up plants just to duplicate this amazing look.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Im happy you like the design of the air jellies. This specific species of air plant have harder lower leaves, and are perfect for the airjellies because they dont have roots but you can just simply put the lower leaves inside the jelly and they will stay in with no problem, just make sure when you do your mid week mist on them that you spray about 6 inches away from the bottom being sure to saturate the lower leaves as well as the top leaves in mist. To make sure your Air jellie stay green, fresh, and healthy, no matter what season.

title: Quick print low friction spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a low friction spool holder that is printed very quick, even on small printers.
Print Volume needed: 100mm x 40mm x ~10mm.

It's designed as a first spoolholder for your printer or as a flexible backup solution.
The printtime is quite short and bad print quality or bad filiament doesn't really matter.

Have fun!

Printer:

Trinus by Kodama

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200µm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print as you want, it's designed to be very forgiving for bad quality etc.

You probably need to sand down some edges and corners of the parts a tiny bit so they will fit together.

You will need four ball bearings (I took 8mm inside, 22mm outside diameter) to make it work. you can adapt the parts to different diameters quickly.

author: Retikulum

print_settings.Notes:: Supports is needed to print diffuser

title: Pear effector - v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This effector were inspired by Kirill91's one (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1569106), designed for E3D-V6.
I wanted one for E3D-V5 (and E3D-V5 clones), and this is an improved version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2208759.

Pay attention: I used small axial fan (http://tinyurl.com/l3kpx46), 25mm X 25mm X 10mm.
I also used some magnets (4mm diameter per 3mm height, from www.supermagnete.it) to join diffuser ("diffusore") with base. This greatly simplify assembly and disassembly without any nuts.
A good idea would be to add some kapton all around aluminium hot block in order to insulate it.
The project is full working on my Kossel mini since 2 months: even though it is simple to dismantle, compared with V1 version, there should some issues concerning total hotend lenght, depending on your nozzle lenght, you have to verify that distance between lower heatsink surface and nozzle tip is at least 25mm, since distance between lower heatsink surface and lower diffuser surface is 21mm.
You can also modify using Solidworks files I added: every file uses a block (SLDBLK file) as reference in order to simplify changes.

Suggestions are welcomed, remix as you like (Solidworks 2017 version)!

Printer:

kossel mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20

Notes:

Supports is needed to print diffuser

title: Nintendo Switch - bluetooth audio clip mount

description.text:
Have a pair of bluetooth headphones? Then say hello to wireless audio on the Nintendo Switch in handheld mode!!

This is a very simple and easy-to-print clip that mounts the TaoTronics Bluetooth 4.1 Transmitter to the back of your Switch so it's secure and out of sight. With the transmitter you can pair your favorite set of BT headphones.

Transmitter: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01EHSX28M?psc=1

The transmitter and clip mount are both super light, so playing in handheld mode feels the same as always.

As shown in the photos, the clip can also be used in dock mode if you're using Elroy Andela's mini dock design (I'm currently in the middle of sanding/painting mine):
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/mini-nintendo-switch-docking-station-32264

No supports needed, I printed this with PLA and it's flexible but strong. I'm sure it'd print great in ABS or PETG as well.

Printer Brand:

Rostock

Printer:

Rostock MAX V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

comments.text: Hi - please could you confirm the dimensions of the clip? When I load the STL into Slic3r it appears to be 110mm x 29mm and a quick test print of the first few layers on my Prusa i3 Mk2 matched this. This is a problem as my Switch is 100mm tall - so the clip is loose by a whole 10mm. It's very strange as the width is accurate - the internal size of the clip matches the 15mm thickness of the Switch. Only the long side of the clip is off. This is doubly strange as it fits the Bluetooth adapter correctly in all dimensions!

title: Printrbot Metal Plus PRINTinZ Plate holder

description.text:
Needed a way to hold the PRINTinZ plate for my Printrbot Metal Plus.
Printed 4 clips to hold the plate (to help it being held down).
And 2 x 2 clips to block moving on X Y axis. I unscrewed some rail holder, and used longer screw so I could use them to hold those clips.
The 2 clips named spill are designed so that they can go over the printbed and push on the PRINTinZ plate to hold it, as the plate does not have exactly the same dimension as the print bed.
(You might need to increase the size 10x)

title: Analog parking brake for driving simulations
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Not happy with analog handbrakes being a pricey investment for us mid-tier sim driving enthusiasts, and all of them designed for racing. I set out to make this.

It features the ratchet locking mechanism and button release of road vehicles (even gives the sound and haptic feedback of one). But simply by removing the pawl's rubberband, it will turn into a drifting brake.
It has 6x6 mm square holes for mounting with zipties or bolts, horizontal or vertical depending on what you prefer

The lever uses an adapter to fit the PVC piping, this means it wouldn't be hard to design a different handle that could slide on in its' stead.

Non 3D printed parts

a lot of it could probably be substituted with something else if you're creative

  • M6 threadless bolt (threadless area about 36mm in length, design shouldn't be too picky about it)
  • M3 screw
  • Wire coathanger cut and bent to fit
  • PVC pipe, mostly because I was unsure if a printed tube would be strong enough
  • Good quality rubberbands
  • WH148 ≤10k potentiometer, ≤15mm shaft. And wires
  • Teensy arduino board (~16$)

Rough guides:

Assembly
Copy/Paste programming the Teensy

Changes history:

  1. July 2017 - Added a lever mk3 with a reinforced rubberband hook. Old version still available.
  2. December 2017 - Bottom "Lever block pin" broke. Added a new version that can be printed horizontally instead of vertical, for more strength.

In action

Standalone demo.
Clipped from streams:
Uphill parking with the ratchet enabled
DiRT Rally with ratchet disabled

Resolution:

0.35 mm

Notes:

Remember to align the prints so that the round shapes and holes come out smooth. The lever and push button are the only parts that could require some supports.

Part specific settings I've used. Not saying they're the correct settings.
Lever: 15% infill, supports
PVC adapter: 90% infill
Walls: 15% infill but also 3 outer shells / vertical shells
Baseplate: 10% infill, 4 outer shells / vertical shells
Pins and rubberband roller: 100% infill
Spur gears: 15% infill, 3 outer shells / vertical shells
